children.definition: Maximum basis point increase to applicable margin the arranger may exercise during flex period. Typically 25-75 bps depending on market conditions.
children.name: Spread Increase Cap

children.definition: Original Issue Discount or upfront fee flexibility, calculated on 4-year average life basis. OID funded via revolver draw in some structures.
children.name: OID / Upfront Fee Flex

children.definition: Right to increase applicable margin by up to specified basis points, adjust OID/upfront fees calculated on 4-year average life basis. Directly impacts borrower cost of capital.
children.name: Pricing Flex

children.definition: Arranger's right to modify non-pricing structural terms: ECF sweep stepdowns, financial covenant levels, reporting requirements, maturity, and amortization schedule.
children.name: Structural Flex

children.definition: Time window during which flex may be exercised: earlier of X days after closing and Successful Syndication. Bank preferred: 60 days; alternative: 45 days or Closing Date.
children.name: Flex Exercise Period

children.definition: Whether revolving facility automatically receives matching margin increases when term facility flex is exercised. Bank preferred includes tag-along.
children.name: Revolver Tag-Along

children.definition: Arranger's right to modify pricing and structural terms during syndication period to achieve successful placement. DLS Preferred section 2 (Market Flex) provides the complete framework: Post-Close Flex Period is earlier of 60 days after closing and Successful Syndication (alternative: 45 days or Closing Date). Pricing Flex includes margin increases (up to agreed bps), OID/upfront fees (with issue price floor), and revolver tag-along flex. Structure Flex and Other Flex are 'TBD based on deal structure.' The flex mechanism allows arrangers to adjust economics downward to clear the market while protecting the borrower through maximum flex limits. Review Template row 49 notes that where precedent includes flex, 'highlight issues in the precedent.'
children.name: Market Flex Provisions

children.definition: Period during which borrower agrees not to issue competing debt that would interfere with syndication. Exceptions: indebtedness issued in lieu of committed facilities, separately committed bridge facilities or notes in lieu thereof.
children.name: Clear Market Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 54 (Clear market); DLS Preferred Row 61 (Clear Market)

children.definition: Framework for identifying and approving syndication participants. Lenders must be reasonably acceptable to borrower (consent not to be unreasonably withheld). Allocation subject to borrower consent (NTURW).
children.name: Lender Selection

children.definition: Borrower obligations to support syndication: providing CIM and marketing materials, attending bank meetings, maintaining public/private information boundaries. Standard period: 60 days post-closing. [4): Ability to request KYC information only available up to date of commitment paper signing, or additional information limited to changes in rules and re]
children.name: Syndication Assistance Obligations
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 63 (Syndication Assistance); KCT Cat 5 Item 4

children.definition: Percentage of underwritten allocation that lead arrangers may place with additional lenders post-signing. Includes minimum economics requirements and timing constraints (typically 15 business days from signing). Neutron extraction context (CL_COMMITMENT_GIVEAWAY): Allocation of underwritten commitments to additional lenders including economics and timing. "Giveaway" describes how much of the underwritten allocation the leads may place with additional lenders post-signing and the minimum economics that must be offered.
children.name: Commitment Giveaway
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 39; Review Template Row 4 (Commitment and giveaway)

CL_COMMITMENT_GIVEAWAY.label: Commitment and Giveaway
CL_COMMITMENT_GIVEAWAY.description: Allocation of underwritten commitments to additional lenders including economics and timing.
CL_COMMITMENT_GIVEAWAY.backgroundExplanation: "Giveaway" describes how much of the underwritten allocation the leads may place with additional lenders post-signing and the minimum economics that must be offered. The commitment papers should define the number of "handed" tickets (pre-allocated to specific lenders), any sponsor-favored allocations, and a floor on economics to preserve parity among the lending group. Additional lenders should not receive greater economics than initial lenders to avoid undermining the original commitment. Giveaway provisions balance arranger flexibility to syndicate with lender protection of their economics.
CL_COMMITMENT_GIVEAWAY.summary_used: Allocation of underwritten commitments to additional lenders including economics and timing. "Giveaway" describes how much of the underwritten allocation the leads may place with additional lenders post-signing and the minimum economics that must be offered.

children.definition: Framework for placing underwritten commitments with additional lenders during syndication period. DLS Preferred section 2 establishes: post-close flex period of 60 days, successful syndication defined as '$0 (except to the extent has determined that it will hold a portion).' Learning Material section on Syndication Provisions covers clear market, lender meetings, CIM preparation, public vs. private information segregation, and DQ lenders. The syndication process includes information memorandum preparation, lender meetings/calls (up to 3), public/private side segregation of MNPI, and clear market restrictions preventing competing debt issuances until successful syndication or 60 days post-closing.
children.name: Syndication Provisions

key_negotiation_axes: duration: standard vs shortened vs none

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; PC Term Comparison: 7. Events of Default - 8.Admin Agency Provisions

children.definition: Fee accruing during commitment period before closing. Flat 1.00% (PC market standard); escalating structures range from 1.75% to 3.50% in sophisticated structures (e.g., Geneva-type).
children.name: Ticking Fee
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 32 (Ticking fee); Review Template Row 141 (DDTL Commitment Fee); Review Template Row 161 (Delayed Draw Ticking Fee)

children.definition: Fee for underwriting commitment, typically same percentage as initial term loans. Standard split: 50% upfront at signing, 50% at each funding.
children.name: Commitment / Underwriting Fee
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 38; Review Template Row 2 (Commitment Letter / Transaction Description); Review Template Row 141 (DDTL Commitment Fee)

children.definition: Fee payable if borrower uses alternate financing within specified period (typically 1 year). Bank preferred: 100% of all fees; alternative: 50%.
children.name: Alternate Transaction Fee

CL_TRANSACTION_DESC.label: Transaction Description
exactPhrases: financing packages with the acquisition structure
definitions of Borrower, Holdings, Sponsor, Acquisition
funding under the facilities occurs substantially concurrently
commitment letter description mirrors the M&A agreement
substantially concurrently with the acquisition close
financing packages with the acquisition structure
definitions of Borrower, Holdings, Sponsor, Acquisition
funding under the facilities occurs substantially concurrently
commitment letter description mirrors the M&A agreement
substantially concurrently with the acquisition close

children.definition: Separate confidential document governing pre-closing and commitment-period fee economics. DLS Preferred section 3 (Fees and Compensation) covers: Term Loan underwriting/arrangement fee (percentage of committed amount, payable at funding), Revolving Facility commitment/arrangement fee, ticking fee (TBD based on commitment length), alternate transaction fee (100% of fees if alternate transaction within one year, with exceptions for rejected opportunities and commitment breaches), breakup fee reimbursement, administration fee, and expense reimbursement (payable whether or not closing occurs). Review Template row 8 notes: 'Fees must be paid at closing and may be netted against proceeds; expenses must be invoiced at least three business days prior to closing.'

CL_EXPENSE_REIMBURSE.label: Expense Reimbursement
exactPhrases: Cap on costs/expenses of Commitment Parties
Expenses only covered to the extent the closing date occurs
invoiced at least three business days prior to closing
Cap on costs/expenses of Commitment Parties
Expenses only covered to the extent the closing date occurs
invoiced at least three business days prior to closing

children.name: Fee Letter Economics
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred section 3 (complete fee specification: underwriting, commitment, ticking, alternate transaction, breakup, administration, expenses); Review Template row 8 (fee payment mechanics)

children.name: Conversion Triggers
children.definition: Events that trigger conversion of bridge loans to term loans or require take-out via securities issuance — typically 180-365 days post-closing without permanent financing, or borrower election to convert.

children.name: Take-Out Provisions
children.definition: Mechanics for replacing bridge financing with permanent capital — securities demand by arranger requiring borrower to issue high-yield notes, exchange offers, or term loan conversion with step-up economics.
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1; LME Provision Language, Protections Against Using a Credit Agreement's Amend-and-Extend Provisions to Carry Out a Non-Pro-Rata LME Exchange (Better Health)

children.name: Maturity Extension Mechanics
children.definition: Roll and extension features if take-out is not completed — automatic conversion to term loan at higher spread, cap on total extensions (typically 1-2 years), and ultimate maturity backstop.

children.name: Economics Step-Up Schedule
children.definition: Escalating pricing on bridge facilities designed to incentivize take-out — spread increases of 25-50bps per quarter, OID adjustments, and the relationship between step-up economics and securities demand pricing.
Right of arrangers to demand securities offering (high-yield notes) in lieu of term loan. Bridge facility converts to term loan if takeout financing is not completed within specified period.

market_benchmarks.typical_trigger: securities demand converts bridge to term loan or high-yield take-out

children.name: Securities Demand / Bridge Facility
Erroneous Payment Definition
children.definition: What constitutes an erroneous payment — any funds transferred by the administrative agent to a lender in error, regardless of amount, including overpayments, duplicate payments, and misdirected payments.

children.name: Clawback Mechanics
children.definition: The agent's right to demand return of erroneously paid funds — typically within 2 business days of notice — overriding any discharge-for-value defense and establishing the payment as agent property until properly allocated.

children.name: Subrogation Rights
children.definition: If the erroneous payment satisfied a borrower obligation, whether the agent is subrogated to the lender's rights against the borrower for the equivalent amount, preserving the claim rather than creating a windfall.

children.name: Interest on Recovery
children.definition: Whether interest accrues on erroneous payments from the date of payment until return — typically at the federal funds rate or overnight bank funding rate — compensating the agent for time-value during the recovery period.
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; PC Term Comparison: 1. Key Definitions - Interest Coverage Ratio (if relevant)

children.name: Lender Acknowledgement
children.definition: Each lender's express agreement to the erroneous payment provisions, waiving discharge-for-value and similar defenses — a post-Citibank/Revlon standard designed to prevent lender retention of mistaken payments.

Requires lenders to disgorge funds transmitted by Administrative Agent in error. Post-2021 LMA/LSTA standard provision (anti-Revlon) addressing Citibank v. Brigade Capital precedent. Now near-universal in new issuance.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

market_benchmarks.standard: discharge-for-value defense waiver, clawback within 2 business days

children.name: Erroneous Payment Provision

children.definition: Date after which commitments automatically terminate if closing has not occurred. Standard: acquisition agreement termination date plus 5 business day cushion. Neutron extraction context (CL_OUTSIDE_DATE): The date by which the acquisition must close and commitments remain available. The "Outside Date" in the commitment letter should track the acquisition agreement's termination date as of signing, typically with a five business day cushion. This keeps commitment availability coterminous with the M&A timeline and avoids having to renegotiate if the seller grants extensions within the acquisition agreement framework.
children.name: Outside Date
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 38; Review Template Row 9 (Countersign date); Review Template Row 11 (Outside Date)

CL_OUTSIDE_DATE.label: Outside Date
CL_OUTSIDE_DATE.description: The date by which the acquisition must close and commitments remain available.
CL_OUTSIDE_DATE.backgroundExplanation: The "Outside Date" in the commitment letter should track the acquisition agreement's termination date as of signing, typically with a five business day cushion. This keeps commitment availability coterminous with the M&A timeline and avoids having to renegotiate if the seller grants extensions within the acquisition agreement framework. The outside date is critical because it determines when commitments automatically terminate if the acquisition has not closed. Some structures automatically track extensions to the M&A outside date while others require separate consent for extension.
CL_OUTSIDE_DATE.summary_used: The date by which the acquisition must close and commitments remain available. The "Outside Date" in the commitment letter should track the acquisition agreement's termination date as of signing, typically with a five business day cushion. This keeps commitment availability coterminous with the M&A timeline and avoids having to renegotiate if the seller grants extensions within the acquisition agreement framework.

children.definition: Events automatically terminating commitment letter obligations: acquisition closes without drawing facility, acquisition agreement terminated, outside date elapses. Optional: non-ratable partial termination.
children.name: Termination Triggers

children.definition: Minimum sponsor equity contribution as condition to closing. Calibrates leverage and establishes sponsor cash-at-risk. Expressed as percentage; may include preferred or qualifying equity. Neutron extraction context (CL_MINIMUM_EQUITY): Minimum sponsor equity contribution requirements and calculation methodology. Minimum equity dictates the sponsor cash at risk and calibrates leverage. Market formulations include preferred or similar qualifying equity, exclude revolver used for working capital, purchase price adjustments and fees from the total sources "denominator," and measure at closing on a pro forma basis.
children.name: Minimum Equity Contribution

CL_MINIMUM_EQUITY.label: Minimum Equity Contribution
CL_MINIMUM_EQUITY.description: Minimum sponsor equity contribution requirements and calculation methodology.
CL_MINIMUM_EQUITY.backgroundExplanation: Minimum equity dictates the sponsor cash at risk and calibrates leverage. Market formulations include preferred or similar qualifying equity, exclude revolver used for working capital, purchase price adjustments and fees from the total sources "denominator," and measure at closing on a pro forma basis. This aligns with market "Ironman" style formulations that focus on cash equity actually contributed at closing. The minimum equity percentage is a key credit metric that determines the sponsor's skin in the game.
CL_MINIMUM_EQUITY.summary_used: Minimum sponsor equity contribution requirements and calculation methodology. Minimum equity dictates the sponsor cash at risk and calibrates leverage. Market formulations include preferred or similar qualifying equity, exclude revolver used for working capital, purchase price adjustments and fees from the total sources "denominator," and measure at closing on a pro forma basis.

children.definition: Governance framework for the period between commitment letter execution and facility closing. Learning Material sections on Commitment Letter Body cover: addressee, commitments (several not joint), titles/roles, economics giveaway (15 business days to allocate up to 35% to additional commitment parties), syndication assistance, information representation, indemnity, expense reimbursement, countersign date, termination of commitments (automatic upon acquisition close without use or agreement termination), and outside date (five business day cushion to acquisition agreement termination). Review Template rows 2-11 cover the commitment letter structure from transaction description through outside date.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Commitment Period Mechanics

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: 5 business days after Acquisition Agreement termination date
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Same as Acquisition Agreement termination date, expected no later than [x] days from signing

children.definition: Categories of due diligence permitted or required: financial (books & records, quality of earnings), legal (litigation, regulatory), environmental (Phase I/II), insurance review, and real estate appraisals.
children.name: Diligence Scope

children.definition: Legal standard defining when the due diligence condition precedent is considered satisfied, ranging from 'in the sole discretion of the administrative agent' (most lender-favorable) to 'reasonably satisfactory to the administrative agent' (market standard) to 'substantially consistent with the information provided during syndication' (most borrower-favorable in commitment letter contexts).
children.name: Satisfaction Standard

children.definition: Condition precedent requiring lenders to complete satisfactory review of the borrower's business. DLS Preferred row 14 (DDTL) condition (xii) specifies: 'the Delayed Draw Term Lenders shall have completed their business, financial, legal, collateral, tax environmental and accounting due diligence of the Target for such Permitted Acquisition and each such review shall be satisfactory to the Delayed Draw Term Lenders in their sole discretion.' DLS Preferred row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions) conditions (vii)-(ix) require delivery of: description of acquisition and agreement, historical financial statements for three years, pro forma information, QoE report from nationally recognized accounting firm, and environmental reports. Under SunGard conditionality for the initial closing, diligence is typically limited to specified closing conditions.

CL_INFORMATION.label: Information
exactPhrases: Supplementation of information cures all breaches
no obligation to disclose to market data collectors
Supplementation of information cures all breaches
no obligation to disclose to market data collectors

children.name: Due Diligence

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited or no additional due diligence beyond Acquisition Agreement representations
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Satisfactory completion of business, financial, legal, collateral, tax, environmental and accounting due diligence

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 14 condition (xii) (DDTL: complete due diligence to lender satisfaction); DLS Preferred row 82 conditions (vii)-(ix) (acquisition diligence: financials, QoE, environmental)

children.definition: Condition precedent requiring the borrower to obtain all governmental and regulatory approvals necessary for the credit facility and the underlying transaction. Includes HSR Act clearance for acquisitions, state insurance or banking regulatory approvals for regulated borrowers, and foreign investment approvals for cross-border transactions.
children.name: Regulatory Approvals

children.definition: Condition precedent requiring the absence of material litigation or governmental proceedings that could reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect on the borrower or the transactions. Scope is typically limited to proceedings commenced or threatened in writing after the commitment letter date, preventing pre-existing known litigation from blocking closing.
children.name: No Material Litigation

children.definition: Pre-closing condition requiring receipt of material third-party consents (regulatory approvals, landlord consents, contract consents) and absence of material litigation that would impair the transaction or the collateral. DLS preferred: all material consents obtained and no material litigation pending as a condition to closing.

market_benchmarks.prevalence: high -- standard in acquisition financing CPs
market_benchmarks.typical_scope: material consents, regulatory approvals, HSR clearance

children.name: Third-Party Consents / Litigation

children.definition: Standard for lender/agent consent to acquisition agreement amendments: no amendment without agent consent (strongest), no 'material' amendment without agent consent (market), or no consent required (weakest / SunGard).
children.name: Consent Standard

children.definition: What constitutes a 'material' amendment to the acquisition agreement: changes to purchase price (any vs. >X%), changes to closing conditions, changes to indemnification provisions, or changes 'adverse to lenders'.
children.name: Materiality Definition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 53 (Amendments to Acquisition Agreement)

children.definition: Restriction on the borrower's ability to amend, modify, or waive material terms of the acquisition agreement (purchase agreement, merger agreement) without lender consent after commitment but before closing. DLS preferred: no material amendments without agent consent. Critical because changes to purchase price, earnouts, reps/warranties, or closing conditions can materially alter the credit profile.

market_benchmarks.typical_standard: no material adverse amendment without lender consent

children.name: Amendments to Acquisition Agreement
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 38 (Termination date); DLS Preferred Row 44 (Business MAC); DLS Preferred Row 53 (Amendments to Acquisition Agreement); DLS Preferred Row 55 (Absence of other debt); DLS Preferred Row 58 (Other conditions); Review Template Row 10 (Termination of commitments); Review Template Row 11 (Outside Date); Review Template Row 153 (MAC)

definition: Pre-closing mechanics and conditions precedent that must be satisfied before the credit facility funds on the closing date. Under Sungard conditionality (the market standard for acquisition financing), closing conditions are intentionally limited to prevent 'conditionality creep' that could allow the arranger to refuse funding. DLS Preferred closing conditions include: termination date tied to acquisition agreement (with 5 BD cushion), minimum equity contribution (percentage of pro forma capitalization), business MAC (defined by reference to acquisition agreement), financial statements (3 years audited within 90 days, quarterly within 30 days, monthly within 30 days), pro forma financials including pro forma EBITDA, forecasts (quarterly for 12 months, annual for facility life), marketing period (20 consecutive BDs), payment of fees/expenses (invoiced 3 BDs prior), collateral delivery (stock certificates, UCC filings, IP filings at closing; remaining perfection within 30-60 days), Specified Representations accuracy, acquisition agreement amendments (no materially adverse changes without consent), absence of other debt, solvency certificate, and PATRIOT Act/KYC compliance.
name: Pre-Closing Mechanics
definition_source: DLS Preferred rows 38-58 (complete closing conditions specification: 18 categories with preferred positions and alternatives); Review Template rows 51 (Reps/Conditions); Learning Material section 2 (Transaction Description/Conditions Precedent: 18 CP categories)
